sp.p: S'bodikins, I recollect his Face—it is he ſure enough—why there has not been a Word of this in the Papers.

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: It's even ſo, notwithſtanding, Sir.—Upon my Soul, this Affair has compoſed me ſtrangely. Thus give me Leave, Sir, to atteſt at once my Duty and my Joy. (kneels.)

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Why, you have my Bleſſing, Boy, I am heartily glad to ſee thee—I did not know you again, you're in ſuch a Kind of Diſguiſe—mayhap now, you can tell—why you look very well—I'm glad to ſee thee, Jack, I am indeed—pray now—mayhap, I ſay, you can tell what the Spaniards are doing in the Bay of Honduras?

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: All in good Time, Sir,—my dear Bellmour I muſt embrace you, Faith the Whimſicalneſs of my Fortune had like to bring about an odd kind of an Adventure,—and make me rob my Father of his Daughter, my Friend of his Miſtreſs, and go to Bed to—my dear Siſter, whom I left a prattling Infant, when I went out of England,—I muſt embrace you.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Tho' your Departure from England was too early for my Recollection, yet my Heart feels a ready Inclination to make Acquaintance with you; and I ſhall ever bleſs the Hour that has given to my Father ſo good a Son, to Mr. Bellmour ſo warm a Friend, and to me tho unexpected Happineſs of a Brother, whom I deſpair'd of ever ſeeing.—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Pray now Jack, how may Ships of the Line has the Admiral with him?—a-propos, that may be in your Letter.—Let me read it.—

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: You may ſpare yourſelf that Trouble,—it was but to acquaint you with what I ſhall now tell you in Perſon, that ſince I find you are become a voluntary Stateſman, I have a Fortune ſufficient to ſupport you in the Study of Politics for the reſt of your Life.—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Have you?—What, and ſhall I have every Thing that comes out?

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: Every Thing, Sir,—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: And Sir, an Apartment at my Houſe in the Country you ſhall ever command.—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: No, no, I can't go to the Country,—that is not the Scene of Action.—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: You ſhall have all the Papers down there.—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Shall I,—but are there any Coffee-Houſes in your Neighbourhood in the Country?

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p: Several!

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: And are there any Politicians there?

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
Swarms of e'm, there's the Curate, and the Juſtice of
the Quorum, and an Exciſemen, and a yellow Admiral, and an Attorney, and—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Ay!—why then that will do—that will do—(going returns) but d'ye hear—I won't go into the Country till the Houſe is adjourn'd.

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: Even as you pleaſe, Sir—and in the mean Time the greateſt Favour you can confer upon me, is to give away this Lady to my Friend Bellmour—

sp.speaker: QUID.
sp.p: Why, ſince I find he knows ſo much of the Matter, I could find it in my Heart to accede to the Treaty; here, here, take her—but ſhould not all this be in the Papers?—I'll go and tell 'em the News myſelf.

sp.speaker: TERM.
sp.p: My Stars and Garters! what a ſudden Evolution here is in Things? fakins, now I looks at him again, I does not believe he is a Highwarman—By my troth, the young Gentleman has a Jen ſcai about him that I likes well enough, and I could find it in my Heart to make him an Advowſon of my Love, and calcine my Perſon to him.

sp.speaker: ROVE.
sp.p: Prithee, Bellmour, how long has my Father had this Turn?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Since the laſt Rebellion; ſince which there has not been an Affair of any Importance in Europe but he has taken a conſiderable Share in it—while his own Affairs have been mouldering into ruin.—

sp.speaker: BELL.
sp.p:
But henceforward all Volunteers in Politics ſhould take Warning from his Example, before they concern themſelves about the Balance of Europe, to have ſome Care of the Balance of their Accounts. The firſt Step towards being a good Citizen, is to be a good Man, and to act with Propriety in the various Relations of Life—and if every
one in the Kingdom would reſolve upon the ſame, the Nation in general would ſoon feel the Benefit of it.

lg.l: Then ſhou'd not ſigh the Stateſman of Cheapſide,
For Poland's Queen—while be neglects his Bride;

l.hi: Then needy Shopkeepers no moreſhould meet,
To roaſt a Miniſter—yet want to eat;

lg.l: Nor ſhou'd th' Upholſt'rer ſlight his Daughter's Cauſ •
For Nabobs, Cherokees, and Catabaws:

l.hi: But Virtue then, the State's enliv'ning Soul,
Should riſe from Individuals to the whole,
The balanc'd Paſſions due Proportion bear,

lg.l: And every Harriet find a Father's Care.
